conclusion: To determine if the two objects have the same acceleration at time \( t_1 \), analyze the velocity-time graphs for both objects.
Calculate the acceleration for each object at \( t_1 \) using the slope of the tangent to their velocity curves at that time.

The image shows two velocity-time graphs, labeled as Object A and Object B. Both graphs start at the origin, indicating zero initial velocity. Object A's graph is a parabola, while Object B's graph is a straight line. The time points \( t_1 \), \( t_2 \), \( t_3 \), and \( t_4 \) are marked on the horizontal axis.
Acceleration is the rate of change of velocity with respect to time. It can be calculated as the slope of the tangent to the velocity-time graph at any given time.

premise: The velocity-time graph for Object A is a parabola.
conclusion: At time \( t_1 \), the slope of the tangent to this parabola represents the acceleration for Object A.

premise: The velocity-time graph for Object B is a straight line.
conclusion: At time \( t_1 \), the slope of the tangent to this line represents the acceleration for Object B.

premise: To determine if the accelerations are the same, compare the slopes of the tangents at \( t_1 \) for both objects.
conclusion: Since the slope of the tangent at \( t_1 \) for both objects is the same, the acceleration of both objects at time \( t_1 \) is the same.

premise: Since both curves are quarter-circle arcs, from the graph it is known that at time \( t_1 \), the absolute value of the slope of the tangent to the curve is equal to the slope of the straight line, i.e., the magnitudes of the accelerations are equal but the directions are opposite.
conclusion: Therefore, the accelerations of the two objects are different at time \( t_1 \).
